title: The Simple Act of Devotion
sub_title: Tending the Garden of Your Soul
devotional:
Old Mrs. Gable had a tradition. Every morning, before the sun fully crested the horizon, she would sit on her porch swing with a steaming mug of tea and her well-worn Bible. She wouldn't just read; she would converse with the scriptures, highlighting verses that spoke to her heart, and whispering prayers of gratitude and supplication. It wasn't a ritualistic obligation but a genuine outpouring of her soul to the One she loved.

One blustery November morning, a young man named Ethan, burdened by anxieties and a creeping sense of purposelessness, noticed Mrs. Gable on her porch. He hesitated, then cautiously approached, drawn by an unseen force. "Mrs. Gable," he began, "I see you here every morning. What is it you do?" 

She smiled warmly, her eyes crinkling at the corners. "I spend time with my dearest friend," she replied, gesturing to her Bible. "I nurture my devotion. Just like a garden needs tending, so does my soul. This is where I find peace, guidance, and strength."

Ethan confessed his struggles, his feeling of being adrift. Mrs. Gable listened patiently, then offered a simple invitation: "Come, sit with me tomorrow. You don't have to read, or pray. Just be present. Sometimes, simply being in the presence of love can make all the difference."

For weeks, Ethan joined Mrs. Gable on her porch. Slowly, he began to open his own Bible, tentatively exploring the Psalms and Gospels. He discovered that devotion wasn't about grand gestures or flawless piety, but about a simple, consistent commitment to seeking God's presence in his life. It was about tending the garden of his soul, pulling out the weeds of doubt and anxiety, and planting seeds of faith and hope. The cold November air seemed less biting, the world less bleak. He found a purpose not in striving, but in simply being devoted.
image_description: A cozy front porch with a wooden swing, a steaming mug, and an open Bible resting on a cushion. Autumn leaves gently swirl on the porch floor.
insights: Ethan's journey illustrates the profound impact of devotion. As highlighted in Luke 10:42, Jesus praises Mary for choosing 'the good portion,' which is sitting at His feet and listening to His teaching, in contrast to Martha's frantic busyness. This 'good portion' speaks to the priority of devotion—setting aside time to connect with God, learn from His word, and cultivate a relationship with Him. Furthermore, Psalm 1:2-3 describes the blessed person as one whose 'delight is in the law of the Lord, and on his law he meditates day and night,' illustrating the fruits of consistent devotion: stability, flourishing, and purpose.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have neglected my devotion to You. I get caught up in the busyness of life and forget to nurture my soul. Help me to prioritize time with You each day, to seek Your presence, and to cultivate a deep and abiding love for You. Teach me to find joy and peace in Your word, and guide me to live a life that is pleasing in Your sight. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What does devotion look like in your life? What are some practical ways you can cultivate a deeper connection with God amidst the demands of your daily routine? What distractions prevent you from nurturing your soul?
